AGAs have been found in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients with neuropsychiatric manifestations of the disease. In particular, anti-GM1 antibodies were associated with neuropsychiatric manifestations, highlighting their predictive and, potentially, prognostic value.
66, 67 Also celiac disease (CD), which can have a variety of neurological manifestations, e.g cerebellar ataxia, peripheral neuropathy, epilepsy and depression
68, 69 , has been associated with anti-GM1 antibodies.
70 The trigger that induces the generation of AGAs is not known. However, it is possible that the formation of complexes between gliadin and GM1 leads to the generation of anti-GM1 antibodies as a “side product”.
71, 72 AGAs have also been found in patients with type 1 diabetes but their correlation with the development of diabetic neuropathy has not been confirmed.
